title: Rohingya refugees continue to arrive in Bangladesh
description:
(28 Sep 2017) The stream of Rohingya refugees fleeing Myanmar into Bangladesh has continued unabated, with the United Nations saying that the number has now topped 500,000 people since August. 
Bangladesh and aid agencies operating there are struggling to provide shelter and basic facilities for the Rohingya who are packed into refugee settlements and banned from leaving.
But the boats keep coming. 
At Shah Porir Dwip, a town at Bangladesh's southern tip, hundreds of Rohingya were seen walking towards Teknaf in search of shelter on Thursday. 
Rasida Begum, who crossed over to Bangladesh on Wednesday night, said her husband was killed by a mob of Buddhist monks. 
She said she had to give her ear ring to the boat man to pay for the ride to safety. 
A mother of two young sons, she could only save one during the perilous journey.
Myanmar's military launched what they called clearance operations after Rohingya insurgents targeted security forces in attacks on 25 August.
The refugees say Buddhist mobs and Myanmar soldiers set entire villages on fire and shot at villagers indiscriminately.
The UN human rights chief has called the attacks "a textbook example of ethnic cleansing."
On Thursday the UN deputy spokesman Farhan Haq said that the total number of Rohingya refugees in Bangladesh was believed to be well over 700,000 people.
